tourBios.carHigh:
Member of the Web.com Tour in 2007-09 and 2011. Member of the PGA TOUR in 2012. 

2012: Finished his rookie season on the PGA TOUR No. 162 in the standings, failing to advance to the FedExCup Playoffs. Finished T24 at the Valero Texas Open for the best of his two top-25 finishes. 

2011: In his fifth full season on the Web.com Tour (2007-11), earned his PGA TOUR card for the first time with a No. 10 finish on the official money list...Earned his first top-10 of the season, with a T8 at the Midwest Classic in Kansas City...Birdied the final two holes Sunday for a final-round 65 and a 14-under total to get into a three-man playoff at the Soboba Golf Classic with Andres Gonzales and Ted Potter, Jr. Eliminated on the first extra hole when he missed a 15-foot birdie putt. Finished the week T2 in Fairways Hit and No. 2 in Putting. Earned enough money to vault from No. 60 to No. 23 on the money list with only five events left on the schedule...Followed that performance with a T7 finish at the WNB Golf Classic, where he was on the leaderboard throughout the weekend and was tied for the lead at one point on the back nine Sunday...Earned his second Web.com Tour title in October (and first since rookie season in 2007), at the Children's Hospital Classic in Chattanooga, making three eagles (Nos. 6, 14, 15) in his final-round 64 to defeat Monday qualifier Brice Garnett by two. An 18th-hole birdie sealed the victory. He began the day four shots back of leader John Mallinger in fourth place and moved from 21st on the money list to fifth...At the Argentine Open in mid-December, he was one of two players to shoot a tournament-low 65 on the final day, good enough for him to move into a T4 at his national open.

2010: Played 26 Web.com Tour events, with one top-10 finish to his credit. Ended the year No. 86 on the money list with five top-25s. Posted his lone top-10 in his seventh start, at the South Georgia Classic, where he finished T9. It was his fifth cut in seven starts. Shot 70-70 in the first two rounds before faltering to a third-round 76. Rallied in the final round to shoot 68. 

2009: Made nine cuts in 23 starts, with his best finishes coming early in the year. Was T13 at the Moonah Classic and was T15 at the Chitimacha Louisiana Open. 2008: Made the cut in 14 of 27 starts, with a pair of back-to-back T15 finishes (HSBC New Zealand PGA Championship and Moonah Classic) his best results of the season. 2007: Made the cut in 17 of 25 starts during his rookie season on the Web.com Tour. Finished the season No. 31 on the money list, with $177,712. Won the season-opening Movistar Panama Championship in his first-ever Web.com Tour start, earning full status on Tour through the end of the 2008 season. Gained entry into the field by being one of the top-eight players on the Tour de las Americas order of merit. Fifty-five years after World Golf Hall of Fame member Roberto De Vicenzo claimed the first of his five victories at the Panama GC, the fellow Argentinean walked the same fairways to capture the $99,000 first-place check. Posted a final-round, 5-under 65 to wipe out a five-shot deficit at the beginning of the final round to finish the event at 6-under 274, two shots clear of three players, including PGA TOUR veteran Jim McGovern. The win was the 67th on Tour by an international player, and the fourth by a Latin American, joining Paraguay's Angel Franco and Mexico's Keoke Cotner and Esteban Toledo. The win capped off a streak of 10 straight made cuts to the start the year. Extended his impressive play with made cuts in 14 of his first 15 starts, culminating with a T3 finish at the Preferred Health Systems Wichita Open. Struggled the rest of the season, missing the cut in seven of his last 10 starts. Posted the last of his three top-10 finishes at the WNB Golf Classic (T10). 2006: Posted his first professional victory at the Movistar Guatemalan Open—a co-sanctioned event on the European Challenge Tour and the Tour de Las Americas. 2005: Earned his European Tour card for the first time by staging a phenomenal comeback at the 108-hole European Tour Qualifying School. Posted a birdie, hole-in-one, birdie finish on the final three holes to gain playing privileges...Has played on several Tours in his career, including the European Tour (2006), Challenge Tour (2004-05), Tour de las Americas from (2003-2004) and the Tour Argentino (2002-03).
tourBios.personal: Got his start in golf as a caddie at age 11. Learned to swing with a tree branch and earned money by selling golf balls he retreived from ponds...Lists Tiger Woods as his hero...Cites winning a playoff in his first professional tournament as his biggest thrill in golf...Called on his girlfriend as his caddie that week because money wasn't available to pay for another. Received his first set of clubs at age 13...Is the fifth of eight children.

tourBios.exmtStatus: Conditional - Finished 151-200 on 2013-14 PGA TOUR FedExCup Points List
tourBios.carHigh:
2014: Second full season on the PGA TOUR included five made cuts in 15 starts. Finished the season No. 189 in the FedExCup, with a T17 at the Barracuda Championship and T18 at the Travelers Championship his best finishes. Closed with a final-round 63 at TPC River Highlands for his career-low round on the PGA TOUR...On the Web.com Tour, competed in 12 events, making the cut in half of them. Top performances were a T31 at the season-ending Web.com Tour Championship. Missed the cut in the other three Finals tournaments. Other top finishes of T33, T36 and T39 came in Regular Season events. Finished 104th on the money list...In four Latinoamérica appearances in November and December, finished 13th, T47, T21 and T9 in the Tour's season finale, the Argentine Open.

 2013: Back on the Web.com Tour, played 25 tournaments, making 17 cuts, with three top-10s, which came at the News Sentinel Open (T2) in August, the Stadion Classic at UGA (T5) in early May and the WNB Golf Classic (T7) in April. Finished No. 23 on the money list to secure his return to the PGA TOUR...Made three Latinoamérica starts, with his best showing a T4 in the Chile Open in November.

 2012: Finished his rookie season on the PGA TOUR No. 162 in the standings, failing to advance to the FedExCup Playoffs. Finished T24 at the Valero Texas Open for the best of his two top-25 finishes...In two Web.com Tour starts, finished T28 and T31...Also made two Latinoamérica appearances, missing the cut and recording a T2, four back, at the Argentine Open after firing four rounds in the 60s.

2011: In his fifth full season on the Web.com Tour (2007-11), earned his PGA TOUR card for the first time with a No. 10 finish on the official money list...Earned his first top-10 of the season, with a T8 at the Midwest Classic in Kansas City...Birdied the final two holes Sunday for a final-round 65 and a 14-under total to get into a three-man playoff at the Soboba Golf Classic with Andres Gonzales and Ted Potter, Jr. Eliminated on the first extra hole when he missed a 15-foot birdie putt. Finished the week T2 in Fairways Hit and No. 2 in Putting. Earned enough money to vault from No. 60 to No. 23 on the money list with only five events left on the schedule...Followed that performance with a T7 finish at the WNB Golf Classic, where he was on the leaderboard throughout the weekend and was tied for the lead at one point on the back nine Sunday...Earned his second Web.com Tour title in October (and first since rookie season in 2007), at the Children's Hospital Classic in Chattanooga, making three eagles (Nos. 6, 14, 15) in his final-round 64 to defeat Monday qualifier Brice Garnett by two. An 18th-hole birdie sealed the victory. He began the day four shots back of leader John Mallinger in fourth place and moved from 21st on the money list to fifth...At the Argentine Open in mid-December, he was one of two players to shoot a tournament-low 65 on the final day, good enough for him to move into a T4 at his national open.

2010: Played 26 Web.com Tour events, with one top-10 finish to his credit. Ended the year No. 86 on the money list with five top-25s. Posted his lone top-10 in his seventh start, at the South Georgia Classic, where he finished T9. It was his fifth cut in seven starts. Shot 70-70 in the first two rounds before faltering to a third-round 76. Rallied in the final round to shoot 68.

2008: Made the cut in 14 of 27 starts, with a pair of back-to-back T15 finishes (HSBC New Zealand PGA Championship and Moonah Classic) his best results of the season. 

2007: Made the cut in 17 of 25 starts during his rookie season on the Web.com Tour. Finished the season No. 31 on the money list, with $177,712. Won the season-opening Movistar Panama Championship in his first-ever Web.com Tour start, earning full status on Tour through the end of the 2008 season. Gained entry into the field by being one of the top-eight players on the Tour de las Americas Order of Merit. Fifty-five years after World Golf Hall of Fame member Roberto De Vicenzo claimed the first of his five victories at the Panama GC, the fellow Argentinean walked the same fairways to capture the $99,000 first-place check. Posted a final-round, 5-under 65 to wipe out a five-shot deficit at the beginning of the final round to finish the event at 6-under 274, two shots clear of three players, including PGA TOUR veteran Jim McGovern. The win was the 67th on Tour by an international player, and the fourth by a Latin American, joining Paraguay's Angel Franco and Mexico's Keoke Cotner and Esteban Toledo. The win capped off a streak of 10 straight made cuts to the start the year. Extended his impressive play with made cuts in 14 of his first 15 starts, culminating with a T3 finish at the Preferred Health Systems Wichita Open. Struggled the rest of the season, missing the cut in seven of his last 10 starts. Posted the last of his three top-10 finishes at the WNB Golf Classic (T10). 2006: Posted his first professional victory, at the Movistar Guatemalan Open—a co-sanctioned event on the European Challenge Tour and the Tour de Las Americas. 

2005: Earned his European Tour card for the first time by staging a phenomenal comeback at the 108-hole European Tour Qualifying School. Posted a birdie, hole-in-one, birdie finish on the final three holes to gain playing privileges...Has played on several Tours in his career, including the European Tour (2006), Challenge Tour (2004-05), Tour de las Americas from (2003-2004) and the Tour Argentino (2002-03).

Learned to swing with a tree branch and earned money by selling golf balls he retreived from ponds...Lists Tiger Woods as his hero...Cites winning a playoff in his first professional tournament as his biggest thrill in golf...Called on his girlfriend as his caddie that week because money wasn't available to pay for another. Received his first set of clubs at age 13...Is the fifth of eight children.

tourBios.exmtStatus: 37th on the 2015 Web.com Tour priority list
tourBios.carHigh:
2014: Finished the Web.com Tour season with 24 starts and two runners-up among his three top-10s. Had a seven top-25s and 15 cuts made. Was 37th in the final priority-ranking order...After missing the cut in the season opener in Panama, made the cut in his next 11 events, through the end of June...In March, held the 36-hole lead in the winds at the Cartagena de Indias at Karibana Championship after a 66-69 start. Carded a 73 on Saturday to share the 54-hole lead with two others. Began Sunday's round with eight consecutive pars. Bogeys on Nos. 11, 13 and 14 proved costly, dropping him to T2, five off winner Andrew Landry's pace...In May, fired a bogey-free 65 in the first round of the BMW Charity Pro-Am. After a second-round 68, found his groove at Green Valley CC on Saturday. Started bogey-par, the posted five consecutive birdies for a front nine of 31. Went on to shoot 66. Started the final round four back. Never threatened the leaders but closed with a birdie on the 72nd hole for a T4...At the next event, recorded his second runner-up of the year, the Rex Hospital Open. Posted 70-68-65 and was T15 after 54 holes. Closed with a flawless 64 that put him in a tie with Patton Kizzire and Kyle Thompson at the end of regulation. After the trio all parred the first extra hole, Thompson rolled in a short birdie putt for the win. It was the second time he lost a playoff to a birdie on the second extra hole. Climbed to fifth on the money list...Play in July and August fell off as he missed six cuts in his last eight tournaments...Finished the Regular Season 16th in earnings and secured his return to the PGA TOUR in 2015-16...In the Web.com Tour Finals, made two of four cuts, recording a T30 in Charlotte and a T35 at the Web.com Tour Championship.

2013: Finished with three top-10s, including a runner-up, eight top-25s and 17 cuts made in 25 starts...In April, collected his first top-10 finish, at the WNB Golf Classic, a T7 at Midland CC...Added a T5 at the rain-shortened Stadion Classic at UGA three weeks later...Enjoyed four sub-70 rounds at the News Sentinel Open to record a T2 in Knoxville in mid-August. Held a share of the lead late in the final round when he birdied the 16th hole. A bogey on his 17th hole knocked him from contention. His performance was his best on Tour since he won the Children's Hospital Classic, also in Tennessee (Chattanooga), in 2011...Nailed down his 2013-14 PGA TOUR card with strong performances sandwiched around his play at Fox Den CC. A T14 in the Price Cutter Charity Championship preceded Knoxville and a T12 at the final Regular Season event, the Cox Classic, allowed him to improve six spots on the money list the last week and finish No. 22...After missing the cut in the first Web.com Tour Finals' event, played the weekend in the last three, with his top showing a T37. Results were greatly impacted by a final-round 79 at the Nationwide Children's Hospital Championship (T37) and a third-round 78 in the Web.com Tour Championship (T57).

2012: Finished his rookie season on the PGA TOUR No. 162 in the standings, failing to advance to the FedExCup Playoffs. Finished T24 at the Valero Texas Open for the best of his two top-25 finishes.

dyn.dynResults: His best finish on the PGA TOUR in 2016 is T32nd at the Frys.com Open.
dyn.dynStats: He ranks 64th in Driving Distance - Fairway Woo on the PGA TOUR.
